datafield.subfield: 12,437 photographs: color and black-and-white transparencies, slides, negatives ; various sizes.

Collection of photographs taken by Tom Raymond documenting storytellers and audiences at the annual National Storytelling Festival, Jonesborough, Tennessee, from circa 1984 to 2003. Most are 35 mm color slides and negatives. The collection documents the major storytellers and performers at the festival with more than 1,500 photographs of storyteller Ray Hicks taken at the festival over the years and at his home in Beech Mountain, North Carolina.

publicationstmt.publisher: American Folklife Center, Library of Congress

seriesstmt.titleproper: Guides to the Collections in the Archive of Folk Culture

profiledesc.creation: Finding aid encoded by Valda Morris, June 2013

did.head: Collection Summary

physdesc.label: Extent (Graphic Materials)
physdesc.extent: 12,437 photographs: color and black-and-white transparencies, slides, negatives ; various sizes.

repository.label: Location
repository.corpname: Archive of Folk Culture, American Folklife CenterLibrary of Congress

did.abstract: Collection of photographs taken by Tom Raymond documenting storytellers and audiences at the annual National Storytelling Festival, Jonesborough, Tennessee, from circa 1984 to 2003. Most are 35 mm color slides and negatives. The collection documents the major storytellers and performers at the festival with more than 1,500 photographs of storyteller Ray Hicks taken at the festival over the years and at his home in Beech Mountain, North Carolina.

note.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the Library's online catalog. They are grouped by name of person or organization, by subject or location, and by occupation and listed alphabetically therein.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized by subject and then by format into the following Series: I. Manuscripts; II. Storytellers Performances; III. Various Storytellers; IV. Events.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Tom Raymond donated the collection to the American Folklife Center in 2009.

processinfo.head: Processing History
processinfo.p: The collection was processed by Valda Morris with assistance from Sara Cleto, Briel Kobak, Abby MacLean, and Amie Pleasant, 2011-2012. Valda Morris revised and encoded the finding aid in June 2013.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: The International Storytelling Collection (AFC 2001/008) has manuscript, sound, graphic and visual documentation related to this collection.
Tom Raymond's early 1980s photographs of the National Storytelling Festival are included in the American Folklife Center's International Storytelling Collection (AFC 2001/008).

userestrict.head: Copyright Status
userestrict.p: Duplication of collection materials may be governed by copyright and other restrictions.

accessrestrict.head: Access and Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Collection is open for research; access to collection materials may be restricted. To request materials, please contact the Folklife Reading Room at http://hdl.loc.gov/loc.afc/folklife.contact

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Tom Raymond Collection (AFC 2009/029), Archive of Folk Culture, American Folklife Center, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.p: Images of the storytellers pictured this collection can be found in Tom Raymond's book, Timeless voices: Images of the International Storytelling Festival. International Storytelling Press of the International Storytelling Association, 1997.

bioghist.head: Biographical History
bioghist.p: Tom Raymond, the official photographer for the International Storytelling Festival from 1980-2009, began working with the International Storytelling Center, formerly known as the National Association for the Preservation and Perpetuation of Storytelling (NAPPS), beginning in circa 1980. In 1983, Raymond established Fresh Air Photo, a commercial photography and post production studio based in Johnson City, Tennessee.

Raymond first pursued a medical career. He earned a B.S. at the University of Tennessee in Knoxville. He later obtained his M.S. at East Carolina University in Greenville, North Carolina, and a Ph.D. in biological science at the Bowman Gary School of Medicine at Wake Forest University in Winston-Salem. Three postdoctoral positions followed at the University of Iowa, the University of Oregon Health Sciences Center, and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. In 1978, Raymond joined the faculty of the Department of Internal Medicine at East Tennessee State University.

Raymond's career in photography began as an undergraduate at the University of Tennessee (UT) while he was working for The Daily Beacon, a student publication. He earned several awards for photojournalism while at UT, but photography was put on hold while he pursued a career in academic medicine. Having published more than 60 peer-reviewed articles in scientific journals and presented his research at meetings throughout the United States and abroad, he resigned from UT in 1987 to pursue photography full-time as the owner of Fresh Air Photo.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The Tom Raymond Collection documents the performances of international and national storytellers at the International Storytelling Festival in Jonesborough, Tennessee. The collection primarily consists of graphic images which span 20 years, 1983-2003. Raymond's photographs of International storyteling performances prior to 1983 are found in the International Storytelling Collection (AFC 2001/008).

The bulk of the collection contains color slides, but also includes negatives, color reversal film, contact sheets and photographic prints. The images mainly capture the on-stage performances of the featured tellers but also capture the storytellers on the grounds of the festival as well as publicity photographs of storytellers.

Of note in the collection are Raymonds 1500 photos of Appalachian storyteller Ray Hicks from Beech Mountain, North Carolina. Also in the collection is Raymond's documentation of Hicks' Home Going Service when he passed away in 2003.
